p: Although known for nearly three hundred years, our knowledge and comprehension about the geographical distribution of species of the family Ceratophryidae leaves much to be desired [ 7, 8]. What we know about them is restricted to sparse information on their feeding habits, reproduction and development of a few species [ 9â€“ 14]. Such lack of knowledge is directly due in part to their cryptic fossorial habits [ 8, 15, 16], making it difficult to study adequately the ecological role they play.
